Headline.Para: Big Ears Goes Electronic; The annual Big Ears Festival again featured artists eager to experiment, including a slate of talented electronic artists who pushed the genre in new directions.

TailParas.Para: Musicians eager to improvise and experiment ruled the day again at the latest installment of the annual Big Ears Festival, held here last week. There were multiple jazz performances by Roscoe Mitchell, Jason Moran, Tyshawn Sorey, Craig Taborn, the members of Medeski Martin & Wood and others. Appalachian folk and country music were represented by Anna & Elizabeth, the Jerry Douglas Band, Rhiannon Giddens and Abigail Washburn and her husband, Béla Fleck. Delivering rock were Algiers, Godspeed You! Black Emperor, Meshell Ndegeocello, Suuns and, from Niger, Tal National. Sitarist Anoushka Shankar presented her 2016 "Land of Gold" album; the banjoist Mr. Fleck played with Brooklyn Rider, a string quartet; Wu Fei, master of the guzheng, a Chinese zither, jammed with jazz musicians; Bang on a Can All-Stars and the choir SONUS performed Julia Wolfe's Pulitzer Prize-winning "Anthracite Fields"; and the Knoxville Symphony Strings and bass-baritone Davóne Tines offered a program of hymns and spirituals. Thus, as is the custom at Big Ears, boundaries between forms were obliterated.

So where did that leave modern electronic composer-producers, whose music is preprogrammed to a degree and who typically perform without such meritorious competition for attention? In good stead, it turned out, as their originality, affinity for improvisation and avoidance of pop clichés gave Four Tet, Laurel Halo, Jenny Hval and Kid Koala, each of whom has performed at major rock festivals, standing in the broad spectrum of electronic music offered here.

Electronic music has long been a staple of Big Ears, now in its seventh year, which has emerged as one of the most vital music festivals. It wisely presents veterans who shaped the genre, as indicated by a Friday night set by Wolfgang Voigt, the German composer who last year released "Narkopop" under the stage name GAS, his first album using that moniker since 2000. Performing at the 2,000-seat Tennessee Theatre, he was cloaked in shadows as images of tranquil forests were projected on a giant screen. The music was symphonic in its colors and density, but it lacked spontaneity as too often Mr. Voigt merely spun tracks from "Narkopop" and what may appear on his next album, "Rausch," out in mid-May .

Long an innovator in New York's downtown scene, by shifting readily among art rock, trip-hop and electronica, Yuka Honda embodies the Big Ears ethos. Early in her Saturday afternoon set, she sang above modernist orchestral sounds while shifting among electronic keyboards and a device that altered her voice. About 20 minutes in, she shook up the serene mood with "I Dream About You," a track from 2004's "Eucademix" album. Happily jolted by lively percussion she seemed to compose on the spot—imagine Gene Krupa reincarnated in a drum machine—the audience began to bob and shuffle in place as a joyful air filled the room.

If Big Ears attendees wanted to dance, they could have done so at the double bill later that rain-soaked evening. In an ultimately disappointing set, Kelly Lee Owens, a native of Wales, abandoned the dreamy music of her excellent 2017 self-titled debut in favor of brassy, repetitive techno. However, Four Tet, the stage name of English musician Kiernan Hebdan, followed with a program that was also dance music, but of a subtle kind. He carefully built highly textured percussion tracks on the fly, then folded over them music from his "Beautiful Rewind" (2013) and "New Energy" (2017) albums. On Sunday afternoon, he returned with Mats Gustafsson, the Swedish saxophonist of jazz trio the Thing, to offer a program of pure improvisation. At one point, Mr. Gustafsson blew aggressively; Mr. Hebdan responded by creating complex electronic beats that ducked under the sheets of sound. Later, he withdrew the percussion altogether in favor of eerie choral voices.

Jenny Hval and Laurel Halo took somewhat similar approaches in their separate, satisfying sets. A Norwegian singer-composer, Ms. Hval's recordings are finely wrought, yet here she was in an improvisational mood. Over persistent beats and synthetic waves of sound, Ms. Hval sang, and sometimes screamed, as she unveiled impressionistic stories that were charming and tense. Michigan-born but now based in Berlin, Ms. Halo had drummer Eli Keszler nearby, and their music veered toward free-jazz meets electronic experimentalism. Somber and thoughtful, she added chords and tones via synthesizers, and sang with alluring restraint as the duo transformed tracks from her 2017 album, "Dust."

Taking electronic improvisation to a delightful extreme, Eric San, the Canadian who records as Kid Koala, enlisted the aid of festival attendees by placing them at turntable stations and inviting them to use color-coded discs to reinvent tracks largely drawn from his misty 2017 album, "Music to Draw To: Satellite." At the event I attended, one of five Mr. San held over the weekend, it was difficult to determine what we amateur turntablists were contributing, but we were all deeply engaged as electronica became less abstract and not so mysterious.

Once again providing adventurous music fans with concert experiences that enlighten as well as entertain, Big Ears 2018 welcomed electronic artists who are more readily associated with rock circles. Passing through the open door, those musicians responded in such a way that confirmed they belonged among such exemplary company.
Mr. Fusilli is the Journal's rock and pop music critic. Email him at jfusilli@wsj.com and follow him on Twitter @wsjrock.
